text:
Williamsburg Bridge across the East River under construction. It was begun November 7, 1896 and opened December 19, 1903. Construction cost £15,091,497, and land £9,096,593. Totaling £24,188,090.

B. H. Hellmich
no date
title: Bridges - Williamsburg Bridge - East River - [Construction.]

text:
The Williamsburg (East River) Bridge under construction as viewed southeastward from the Manhattan shore. In the foreground is the area that will be cleared (1939) for the East River Drive. The R. Hoe and Company foundry on the right will shortly be removed.

About 1903-4

Ewing Galloway
title: Bridges - Williamsburg Bridge - [R. Hoe and Company.]
The Williamsburg Bridge

text:
Williamsburg Bridge Plaza, viewing westward between Broadway (left) and South 4th Street (right). The Broadway Elevated Line is seen serpentining its way onto the Williamsburg Bridge.

The domed structure beyond the Sapolio sign is the Williamsburg Savings Bank Building. In the foreground is seen one of the main trolley termini of Brooklyn. The white marble building (car in front thereof) in the right center of the view, houses the Williamsburg Trust Co.

About, 190

Urbrock Collection

(1)
Williamsburg Bridge, as seen from foot of Grand Street, looking east to Brooklyn.

March 1929.
Eugene L. Armbruster, Collection.

(2)
The same, from different angle, showing the ruins of the ferry-house, which burned.

March 1929.
Eugene L. Armbruster, Collection.

text:
(1) The western tower of the Williamsburg Bridge; in the center is part of the old Grand Street ferry-house, at the foot of Broome Stret, now used by a boat club. April 11, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same. A view taken after the destruction of the ferry slip. January 14, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

(3) Another view of the bridge looking towards Brooklyn. June 10, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.
(No. 3 not a dry mount item).

text:
A general view northward from the Williamsburg Bridge, showing on the horizon the 42nd Street-Midtown skyline. From left to right the structures are, the Consolidated Edison Co, Metropolitan Life Insurance Co, New York Life Insurance Co, Empire State, No. 10 E. 40th Street, No. 500 Fifth Avenue, R. C. A. (under construction), Lincoln, Chanin, Chrysler, Hotel Waldorf Astoria (twin spires), General Electric, News and Hotel Woodstock Buildings. View No. 3 centers the Empire State Building between the iron cross ribs of the bridge.

September 18, 1932
Views: 1, 2 and 3

P. L. Sperr
title: General view - [Lower East side of Manhattan - Williamsburg Bridge (North).]

text:
East River, shoreline, east from pier 44 (Jackson Street), showing Corlears Hook Park and the Hecker Flour factory building where the river makes a sharp bend in a northerly direction. Also shown is the Williamsburg Bridge and the shore of the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn (right background).

September 16, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.
title: East River - Shore and skyline of lower Manhattan - South Ferry - Williamsburg Bridge - Jackson Street (East) - Corlears Hook.

East River Drive, (extreme right) south from about East 12th Street, showing the area east of same being filled in. Shown in the background, at Delancey Street, is the Williamsburg Bridge that crosses the East River to Brooklyn. Nos. 2 and 3 of this set are southward from 11th Street. Note the bulkheads and the former pier stumps.

June 4, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

East River Drive, (extreme right) south from about East 12th Street, showing the area east of same being filled in. Note the bulkheads and the former pier stumps.

Exterior (Marginal) Street, south from East 15th to 14th Streets, showing at the latter point a coal crane of the Consolidated Gas Co. (plant on the right). This street will be incorporated in the new East River Drive. In the background appears the Williamsburg Bridge to Brooklyn (left).

September 1937.

George D. Chinn.

Rivington Street, east to South Street. Looking southwards and showing the Williamsburg Bridge and the beginning of the East River Drive.

Manhattan Highways Comm.

February 23rd, 1937.

Williamsburg Bridge: Looking north (view 1) and south from the Manhattan side of the East River.

P. L. Sperr

View 1: 1937
View 2: 1939

text:
Recreations and Hobbies: Swimming off Corlears Hook. At the left is the Heckers Flour Co. plant, obstructing a view of the Manhattan landing of the Williamsburg Bridge. The Brooklyn sector that identifies this structure is in the background. The U. S. Navy Yard there, if shown, would be on the right.

1938-9

Alexander Alland
title: Recreation and hobbies - [Swimming off Corlears Hook.]

text:
East River Drive, west across Gouverneur Slip, showing details of the construction of this new vehicular thoroughfare. This necessitated the removal of a stretch a block wide, extending between South and Front Streets. At the right is Gouverneur Hospital.

No. 2: April 7, 1940
No. 1: November 8, 1939

P. L. Sperr

original_title: Manhattan: East River Drive - Jackson Street
text:
East River Drive, west across Jackson Street, showing the demolished area necessitated by this new marginal highway. This extends from South to Front Streets whereupon appear the buildings shown. In the center is Gouverneur Hospital.

November 8, 1939
April 7, 1940

P. L. Sperr

original_title: Manhattan: East River Drive - Grand Street
text:
East River Drive, at the foot of Grand Street, showing constructional details of the new East River Park that will extend northward on the easterly side (Rivers edge) of this newly completed section. Overhead is the Williamsburg Bridge that crosses the water to Brooklyn.

1-2 May 7, 1939
3 June 1, 1939

original_title: Manhattan: East River Drive - Montgomery Street
text:
East River Drive, east from a point below Montgomery Street, showing constructional details of this new vehicular thoroughfare. The entire block between Front and South Streets has been cleared permitting this to continue as a marginal thoroughfare. On the left is Gouverneur Hospital at Gouverneur Slip. Preceding the Williamsburg Bridge is the open area forming Corlears Hook Park.

April 7, 1940
No's. 1-2-3

P. L. Sperr
